outboundReferences.contextLine: On any plan, a function app requires a general [[azure-storage-account]], which supports Azure Blob, Queue, Files, and Table storage. This is because **Functions rely on Azure Storage for operations such as managing triggers and logging function executions**, but some storage accounts don't support queues and tables.

| Kubernetes       | Fully isolated and dedicated environment running on top of the Kubernetes platform.                                                                                                                                                                                                               | Direct or with [[azure-arc]] | Event-driven autoscale for Kubernetes clusters using KEDA.                                                                                                                                                                                      | Varies by cluster                                                                          |                                |
- Done by assigning a role in [[azure-rbac]] or specifying the identity in an access policy, depending on the service to which you're connecting

inboundReferences.contextLine: Both [[azure-functions]] and [[Azure App Service WebJobs]] are built on top of [[azure-app-service]].

fields.title: AZ-204 - Developing Solutions for Microsoft Azure

inboundReferences.contextLine: There are two ways you can read from the change feed with a push model: **[[azure-functions]] with Azure Cosmos DB triggers**, and the **change feed processor library**. Azure Functions uses the change feed processor behind the scenes, so these are both similar ways to read the change feed.
Both [[azure-functions]] and [[azure-logic-apps]] are Azure Services that enable serverless workloads.

fields.title: Azure Functions vs Azure Logic apps
